comments.commentBody: One of the funnest crosswords I've done in a long time. The feeling of triumph when the theme dawned on me -- that was great!
Personally, I loved Barbara Jordan. Unfortunately, she died. Hillary is the one who is running.

Hillary has never EVER claimed that Barack Obama was born outside the U.S.  And whatever suspicions to that effect may have been promoted by some of her lower-level staff members the fact remains that only Donald Trump refused to accept the legitimacy of the birth certificate and that only Donald Trump has hung on to that scurrilous accusation until just today.  And BTW; the deficit has been cut in half over the past six years.

This insurance company has the worst e-commerce capability on their web site.  They double-billed my home insurance premium to my credit card while I was on vacation and I had to take time to get it fixed.  Very annoying.  But he's okay.

Look around you.  To your left and right.  In the supermarket, in a restaurant, at a ballgame.  Depending upon where in the US you live, 35-55% of those in view are prepared to cast a ballot for a bloviating inveterate liar for President.  And, why, you wonder, are things so badly screwed up?

The cable networks endlessly showed an empty podium as their commentators salivated, and finally The Great Trumpolini spoke.

A grateful Barack Obama finally settled into his office knowing that the Ultimate Authority on Everything had accepted his citizenship and thus confirmed his Presidency as legitimate.

Trump may not understand this yet, but the embrace in which he and the media lovingly exploited each other is about to destroy his candidacy. He renounced birtherism for the best of reasons - taking it off the debates table (if that even works).

But I believe that for once, and when it matters most, his (or rather, his handlers') media instincts let him down and left the Emperor with no clothes. Trump says he has "ended it", but he hasn't. By casting aside birtherism in just a few words but in a blaze of publicity, he has reminded people how offensive he has been over the years, and exposed how casually he can treat the truth.

I would never rule out Hillary's campaign snatching defeat from the jaws of victory, but they are probably heaving a huge sigh of relief right now. Trump's faithful, no doubt, will stay with him, but I can't imagine how others stand by someone so unstable, deceitful and, yes, deplorable.

@David ~ Please stop with the "I think Hillary herself is pretty deplorable."  She isn't!!!  As you wrote "it's time to behave like adults" and campaigning ardently for Hillary Clinton does not include calling her pretty deplorable.  Stop with your mixed messages.

Chelsea may be "assembled by a host of coaches," but its core is the key players from a team that just a couple of seasons ago completely dominated the Premier League for half a season, then went into cruise control but still won the League. That's not a bad group!

Klopp has had time to work with a Liverpool that had lots of bad spells under him in his first year. Let's see where Conte takes Chelsea by the end of his first year and the start of his 2nd. A shame about the inability to get who he wanted on defense. But very far too soon to claim today's Chelsea is the one Conte has put his imprint on.
I thought some of his left footed crosses were quite good. Yes, looking forward to more chances to renew acquaintences, Bakes.

He was markedly better against Chelsea than against Leicester and Spurs, where he seemed all too eager to cut inside onto his right foot.  Fantastic player nonetheless, indispensable at this stage and my would-be captain.

For a fullback, cutting inside has to be a change of pace tactic so the opposing fullback cant just play him to cross. The risk of pulling the whole team out of shape and position is too great to do it often.

Inagree, he's a model pro. He'll throw in 10,000 left footed crosses on the training ground until he's a deadly threat.

Klopp's history at both Mainz and Dortmund has been to blood in and trust youth. I guess he doesn't think he's got a good enough left back yet. The fullbacks in Klopp's system start the attacks and have to cover the most ground.
James Milner is an excellent, versatile pro, showing he can play left back as a right footed player.
Jordan Henderson's goal into the top corner is the early favorite for EPL goal of the year.
Chelsea was just dismal in the first half. They were much improved in the second, but perhaps Conte waited well too long before making his triple change. But Liverpool was hanging on at the end.

He's a magnanimous, gracious hero because he finally admitted that he libeled the President of the United States?  Sorry, but you don't get to speak for "the rest of America" if you think that all of us are that gullible.

Aaron of London, I am sure we are all as surprised as you are. I didn't know it was possible to be shocked every day. We are somewhere between being completely desensitized to trump's remarks and stunned repeatedly. I finally understand how the most repugnant figures in history came into power. Trump channels the worst in people and that apparently overcomes all the obvious weakness in his character and judgement. People don't even need to like him to vote for him. He's given out several positions on every issue and people can just pick the one that they like and hope that that's the one he'll choose in the end.

Yes, and don't forget Ted Cruz - who ran for president to preside over a government for which he has so assiduously worked in recent years to shut down on multiple occasions while holding a seat in the U.S. Senate.  We ALL have the opportunity and obligation to vote for Hillary and then continue straight down the party ballot in order to defeat the GOP majorities in the Senate and House.  There will be continued dysfunction in Congress for the next 4 yrs. if we don't.  GOTV folks...

The Republican party is deplorable.

Their leader is despicable.

Anyone who supports them is un-American. These people have no respect for honesty, truth, the presidency, or anything that comes under the heading of "united" states. I'd say they are the worst any political party could be, except that I'm sure they will descend even further down into further debasement, further on. They, like their candidate, are a bottomless well of worthlessness.

.
I realize that the remark about Texas was made in jest, but I never joke about voting rights.

It is unlawful to require a literacy test or any other proof of aptitude when deciding who may vote. That rule protects illiterates on both sides of the aisle, such as the ones who sent Lyndon Johnson to Washington (where he would eventually strengthen voting rights protections).

I recommend the site 866ourvote.org (or electionprotection.org, which just sends you to the other one) as a source of information about voting rights. It's run by an umbrella group of organizations; the lead organization is the Lawyers' Committee for Human Rights Under Law, which was formed at the behest of Bobby Kennedy in the mid-60s.

If anyone knows of any threat to voting rights -- individual harassment or county-wide purging of voter rolls -- you can contact that umbrella group at 1-866-OUR-VOTE. The group is called "Election Protection"; they regularly present reports to Congress about infringements on voting rights, but they need citizens to report the infringements (because their budget isn't big enough to have investigators in every town).

This charlatan could no more make America great again than PT Barnum could have made his circus into the Supreme Court. Barnum, to his credit would never have had the temerity to try it. He was, in his own unique way, a great salesman. Trump is, in his own way, a liar and a thief. We cannot let him steal from us this country our forebears fought and died for.
Get out the vote for Hillary, or look back on her defeat as, in a real way, our own fault. The chips will fall as we let them.

".... if Trump is elected, the people who support and follow him will simply get what they deserve."
Yes, and they will blame someone else!
Hillary herself did neither.  If you're ready to fall for THIS one you must also be ready to accept Donald Trump as the risen Messiah.

The intoxication by the general food industry started with the post WWII economic development. The concept of supermarket increased the use of cars, forcing shopping outside the walking circle. Sugar started  to be everywhere. Read the labels, your simple dressing got sugar. The only way to stop this health agony is the cook organic grade food from scratch. No customers, no business, no power to continue. Eat simple, good quality, small portion. Millennials want that because they do not want to have diabetes, and other chronic diseases linked to sugar rich food , they do not Know to cook, rethinking simple cooking to be healthy, the market will follow as usual.
This  certainly isn't news it's been going on for years. Say and do anything to make a buck.
Big business giving millions a death sentence for the sake of dollars.
Excellent article, which discloses the manipulation of the government and the American people by the lies of big business.

It only takes three days without sugar or sweeteners for your palette to reset and the cravings to abate.  I think it is because it takes that long for the bad characters in your gut microbiome stop screaming at you to feed them.

I gave up all processed sugar on 11/12/15. I haven't looked back. It was not easy. But it's been worth it.

Yes, sugar is addictive. I agree with you 100% there. And yes, it's difficult to break that addiction. But it is not impossible. It's all about choices.

Once one gets beyond the addiction and realizes how much better they feel every day without a blood stream full of sugar, there'll be no turning back - please believe me on this. I did it. I'm never, ever going back. Sugar is pure poison.

1st Armored Division, next time you get a flu, stop eating sugar. You are so ill anyway, you don't notice the withdrawal and then you can continue with the no sugar plan. I think it takes only 2-3 weeks to get over the physical addiction.

Sugar is a drug and is highly addictive.

Don't belive me, just try going without it for awhile and see how long you last.

Personally I must have been subjected to 60 years of implanted false memory which informed me that sugar in any way, shape and form was the worst possible dietary element for one's health; this doesn't seem to agree with the success of the nefarious propaganda campaign you describe. However, I suppose it is awkward, purely in a linguistic way, to frame a blazing jeremiad of an editorial attacking the evil barons of Big Fat...it doesn't quite have the same ring, does it.

Same thing happened to me: while never a big sugar person, I cut carbs--not the crazy no carb approach that was trendy for a while, but to a reasonable level. One day I looked in the mirror and discovered my stomach had shrunk. I couldn't believe it. The weight came off, after years of trying and failing, and has stayed off.

I tried the same thing as Mary O. - I gave up sugar for a few months and then made up guidelines so I would drastically reduce my refined sugar intake. I too, lost about 6 pounds without any other changes in my eating. I am only 5' tall and started with a normal weight although I wasn't skinny so it was a big percentage of my weight. Interesting experiment. I recommend it.
Congratulations! And there is nothing wrong with your teaspoon of sugar in the morning. Also, you can add milk to your coffee. Unless you have an intolerance, there is nothing wrong with dairy.

A month ago, my younger sister and her husband started an eating program called Whole30, that called for radically reshaping what they ate for 30 days. No sugar, no dairy, no alcohol, no grains. Oh well, I thought, that's too extreme for me, but my brother-in-law was motivated to make some big changes in his eating patterns, because his father is diabetic and has lost both lower legs to the disease.

I've never been a dieter, but as a measure of solidarity with their program, I decided to cut back on sugar intake. I haven't gone cold turkey, I still take a tsp of sugar in my morning coffee. But I'm not eating ice cream and baked sweets, and instead of granola (too sweet) with my morning fruit, I'm eating a handful of almonds instead. Interesting -- in 4 weeks I've lost 6 pounds, and it wasn't much effort.

I'm starting to think this sugar business is pretty insidious. And the best way to fight back is at the micro level, by not buying what they're selling. I'm glad to read that soda sales are declining and seltzer water sales are rising. Little by little, the truth is coming out.
Brilliant!

"Just a spoonful of sugar helps life-expectancy go down,
Life-expectancy go down, left-expectancy go down,
In the most deceitful way!"

"... I felt pressure from the sugar and soft-drink industries, who would vacillate between criticizing my work and trying to hire me."

Could you be more specific? In what form or forum was your work criticized? How did they attempt to hire you?

I spent 20 years researching various effects of sugar on eating and body weight, mostly for NIH-funded grants. But with every move I made, I felt pressure from the sugar and soft-drink industries, who would vacillate between criticizing my work and trying to hire me. I eventually grew disgusted by it all and became a stay-at-home mom, raising my autistic son. Speaking truth to power is an uphill battle, and I wish the next generation good luck!
The point of adding sugar (and salt) to processed food is to hide the taste of the low-quality ingredients being used.

You hit it on the head, Marylou. Nowhere is the manipulation of the sugar industry so apparent and insidious as it is at the consumer level. I'm a HS teacher, and I try to incorporate as much nutritional reading into my curriculum as possible. Talk about an uphill battle...

And many of those junk foods, like Pop Tarts, are covered with "health" labels (7 essential vitamins, real fruit, whole grains, no saturated fat, all natural, blah, blah, blah).

It is an absolute scam that the USDA lets these companies get away with this.

All one has to do is walk down a grocery store aisle to observe firsthand the full extent of the sugar industry's total control of and influence over the American public.   Entire aisles are devoted to cookies, candy and an endless array of sugar soaked empty foods while the mirror image can be found in the frozen foods aisle as well:  entire aisles devoted to ice cream products while the frozen vegetable foods section is less than a third of ice cream.  Addiction by sugar is profoundly real.  I'd like to see an investigation of the "corporate" doctors that come out of the Ivy League.

As long as real starvation is a far bigger problem in the world than a hypothetical danger of Genetic Engineering, we should go with scientific consensus rather than New Age alarmism. And suggesting that, in the era of Global Warming, it is better to lower the efficiency of food production than simply cutting back on consumption, is downright ridiculous.

"Their plea for scientific objectivity may have sounded sensible, but it masked nefarious aims."

It took more than 50 years for JAMA to expose the chicanery employed by the sugar giants. Let's hope it doesn't take the JAMA as long to expose big biotech's manipulation of the EPA, FDA — and itself!

Crops genetically engineered to generate their own poisonous insecticide — Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt) — and immunity to another poison — glyphosate — have so far had a free-ride through regulatory agencies specifically designed to protect the public interest.

To boost an industry emerging in the 1980's, the FDA and EPA chose to rely almost entirely on safety studies that were conducted on rats and for only for a small duration of their full life cycle. To date there have been zero epidemiological or clinical studies done in the USA on human beings regarding the possible harmful effects of two poisons: glyphosate, a probable carcinogen, and Bt.

No cohort studies either and with the July passage of the aptly dubbed DARK Act, serious scientific examination of GE foods' effects on humans has been deterred once again.

Meanwhile, the FDA recently found US honey has residue levels of glyphosate double the limit allowed in the EU.

http://www.huffingtonpost.com/carey-gillam/fda-finds-monsantos-weed_b_12...

The JAMA has exposed big sugar's deceptiveness. Time now for it to re-examine GE foods, an industry much closer to home.

Time for an integrity check, JAMA.
